chapter: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: Question 1: All of the following can be done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except?

options.a: Strap their thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
options.b: Place in prone position to prevent aspiration
options.c: Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
options.d: Roll the patient onto a hard board

questions.explanation:
Patients with polytrauma are shifted into a supine or prone position (not in a lateral position) by 
laying them over a firm surface to restrict spinal movement. As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with 
cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients until proven otherwise are considered to have an 
injured vertebral column. The patients are placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column 
and a rigid cervical collar (philadelphia collar) is applied. Aspiration can be prevented by putting 
the patient in the prone position and strapping can be done to provide further stabilization. Long spine boards with straps are helpful in the rapid transport of the patient from one place to 
another. The patient can be put on the long spine board by log-rolling (a technique where four 
people hold the patient and roll the patient like a log without allowing rotation or bending of the 
spine). Conscious and alert patient indirectly means that they don’t need intubation and their airway is 
patent. If the patient is unconscious always check the airway and if needed, endotracheal 
intubation must be done immediately by various methods. Preferably by direct laryngoscopy and 
intubation.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 2: A man met with a road traffic accident, which resulted in paralysis of both his upper and 
lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What 
will you advise regarding radiography?

options.a: The patient should not be shifted and portable x-ray machine should be used after neck
options.b: Instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.
options.c: Instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray AP and lateral view without any cervical
options.d: Order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical situation suggests a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not 
be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used for radiography after neck stabilization. Management in a trauma patient with a suspected cervical fracture involves the following steps: 156 
Sold by @itachibot • Spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board is the immediate step in 
the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases. • It is followed by a gross assessment of spinal cord function by eliciting extremity movement. 
Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicative of an associated 
fracture. • Imaging is done by X-ray or CT. Portable X-ray machines are preferred to avoid further injury 
while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but 
not the cervicothoracic junction. Cervical CT has been made the modality of choice in most 
emergency departments owing to the high quality of images that can be obtained.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 3: A 25-year-old construction worker sustained an injury to his neck after falling from the tenth 
floor of a construction site. The first aid team that rushed to his rescue log rolled him. 
According to ATLS, what is the minimum number of people required for log-rolling this 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for the safe manoeuvre of log-roll in 
patients suffering from trauma. • The first person is assigned to restrict the motion of the head and neck. • The second person is positioned on the same side of the patient’s torso. He manually prevents 
segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while 
transferring the patient. • The third person is responsible for moving the patient’s legs. • The fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back. Note: In a patient known to have a fracture of the extremities, a minimum of 5 people are 
required to safely perform the log-roll manoeuvre.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 4: 145 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following statements about acute spinal injury is false?

options.a: Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to the loss of parasympathetic tone
options.b: Immediate respiratory suppression can occur due to the involvement of the phrenic nerve
options.c: Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS help to determine the need for radiographic evaluation
options.d: Patients with neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as soon as possible

questions.explanation:
157 
Sold by @itachibot Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to loss of sympathetic tone. The classic presentation of neurogenic shock is hypotension in the setting of warm, well-perfused 
extremities in a paralyzed patient. This condition requires intravascular volume expansion and 
vasopressor support. Option B: High cervical spinal cord injury (SCIs) may have immediate respiratory suppression. 
This requires airway management and ventilatory support because of paresis of the phrenic 
nerves. Hypoventilation can occur from paralysis of the intercostal muscles (injury to the lower 
cervical or upper thoracic spinal cord) or the diaphragm (injury to C3 to C5). Option C: Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS are validated clinical decision tools to help 
determine the need for radiographic evaluation and to clinically clear the cervical spine. NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five 
criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, 
if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further. The NEXUS criteria include: • No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness • No evidence of intoxication • A normal level of alertness • No focal neurologic deficit • No painful distracting injuries Option D: Patients with or without neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as 
soon as possible. A patient who is allowed to lie on the hardboard for more than 2 hours is at high 
risk for pressure ulcers.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 5: A 20-year-old college student sustained a superficial injury to his neck during a bar fight. 
What is the probable cause of sudden death in this patient?

options.b: Air embolism through external jugular vein

questions.explanation:
Air embolism through the external jugular vein is a cause of sudden death in patients with 
superficial neck injury. All other structures are deeper structures, hence are not involved much in superficial injuries of 
the neck.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 6: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department after suffering injuries in the neck 
during an armed robbery. On examination, several bleeding lacerated injuries are visible at 
the front and lateral aspects of the neck. Which of the following is not an indication for 
immediate surgical exploration?
questions.explanation:
Fluid responsive hemorrhagic shock is not an indication for immediate surgical intervention. The following are the indications for immediate surgical exploration of neck trauma. They are also 
known as the hard signs of neck trauma: • Pulsatile bleeding • Expanding hematoma • Air bubbling from penetrating injury 158 
Sold by @itachibot • Absent radial pulse • Respiratory distress • Presence of neurological deficit • Fluid resistant hemorrhagic shock • Audible bruit or palpable thrill • Signs of stroke/ cerebral ischemia The presence of any of these hard signs indicates major neurovascular/ airway injury and is an 
indication for surgical exploration of the trauma region as soon as possible. Neck trauma is classified based on the different regions of the neck. • Zone I: thoracic inlet to cricoid, associated with maximum mortality. It contains large vascular 
structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. • Zone II: cricoid cartilage to the angle of mandible, most commonly prone to injury and most 
easily accessible for surgery. It contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and 
structures of the aerodigestive tract. • Zone III: angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood 
vessels that are difficult to expose surgically. Management: • If the patient is hemodynamically unstable: neck exploration • If the patient is stable: • Zone II injury: Conservative management • Zone I and Zone III: Angiography and angioembolisation are indicated. If it fails then neck 
exploration should be done. 159 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 7: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to 
the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve 
despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next 
step in management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a stab injury and hypotension not responding to IV 
fluids indicates persistent hypotension due to ongoing hemorrhage and the next step in the 
management is to perform an eFAST. Cardiogenic shock or hemorrhagic shock are the most likely causes of persistent hypotension in a 
trauma patient. Ultrasound evaluation using eFAST to look for pericardium, pleural cavities, and 
abdomen in combination with plain radiographs of the chest and pelvis will usually identify the 
source of the bleed. In patients with persistent hypotension due to blunt trauma, the pelvis should be wrapped in a 
sheet for stabilization until radiography can be done. Evaluation of CVP or ultrasound of the IVC may further assist in distinguishing between 
cardiogenic and hypovolemic shock. It is mostly fatal if not controlled, and requires immediate management. Blood and plasma 
transfusions are provided in a ratio of 2:1. Patients with persistent hypotension requiring surgical 
intervention include: • Blunt trauma and massive hemothorax • Penetrating trauma • Hemoperitoneum • Gunshot injuries to the chest or abdomen • Penetrating weapon remaining in place. Other options: Options C and D: CECT can be done only when the patient is hemodynamically stable. Option B: Tube thoracostomy has no role in this patient's management since the X-ray shows 
clear lung fields.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: Question 8: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Among the given options, eFAST(extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) is 
least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma as the sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting 
retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor. FAST is a rapid, noninvasive bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen 
and assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. Technique: • The patient is placed in a supine position • With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned : • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, 
and Morison pouch 160 
Sold by @itachibot • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of 
Douglas eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates Left and right thoracic views to assess for 
pneumothorax and haemothorax. Computed Tomography (CT Scan) is the investigation of choice for retroperitoneal injury, but it 
can only be done in a hemodynamically stable patient.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 9: A 30-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic 
collision. His heart rate is 124 beats/min and BP is 78/56 mmHg on the right arm, and 64/50 
mmHg on the left arm. A portable chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum but normal lung 
and cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of aortic injury. The investigation of choice in this 
hemodynamically unstable patient is transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). In 
hemodynamically stable patients, the investigation of choice is CECT or CT angiogram. Traumatic aortic injuries are commonly seen in deceleration injuries (e.g. road traffic accidents). 
The most common site of aortic injury is the isthmus, near the attachment of ligamentum 
arteriosum. Clinical features of aortic injuries: • Hypotension • Difference in blood pressure in bilateral limbs • Absent pulse in the unilateral limb • Widened mediastinum on chest x-ray Management • Volume replacement: fluid therapy and blood transfusion • Permissive hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as esmolol • Immediate surgical repair: • Endovascular stenting, or • Open surgical repair with Dacron graft
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 10: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib fractures. On examination, you 
notice a paradoxical movement of the chest, and the patient is diagnosed with respiratory 
failure. How would you manage him?

options.d: Internal operative fixation of the fractures segments

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of flail chest with respiratory failure. Management of this 
condition is IPPV (invasive positive pressure ventilation). A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest 
of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib 
fractures i.e., 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an 
underlying pulmonary contusion as well. 161 
Sold by @itachibot On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards, and therefore, less air 
moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards. This is known as paradoxical 
respiration. The diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm, the paradoxical motion of a 
chest wall segment can be observed for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the 
associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at 
high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax. Treatment: • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided. • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or 
epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory 
failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen. Treatment algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure:
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 11: 147 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident says that his bike handle hit the right 
side of his chest. On palpation, he had tenderness in the right upper chest. Chest radiograph 
shows a fracture in the right third rib. Which of the following should you not do while 
managing him?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a rib fracture. Strapping is not done for rib fractures because 
it prevents the patient from taking deep breaths. This can lead to lung collapse. The vital step in the management of rib fractures is to reduce pain and prevent the development 
of pneumonia. Rib fracture causes intense pain during breathing and increases the risk of 
pulmonary infections as the patient is not able to cough forcefully. In mild to moderate cases, pain can be managed by intravenous opioids. In severe cases, patients 
may require epidural analgesia. 162 
Sold by @itachibot In addition to adequate analgesia, chest physiotherapy like deep breathing, frequent coughing, 
incentive spirometry should be encouraged in these patients. This prevents the development of 
pneumonia and lung collapse. When chest wall injuries result in respiratory failure, mechanical 
ventilation should be provided.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old female presents to the ER with a history of RTA. On examination, GCS is 15/15, 
heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is 
hyperresonant on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The left chest appears normal. 
But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen was 
soft. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of trauma with decreased breath sounds and a hyper-resonant note on 
percussion indicates pneumothorax. The presence of tachycardia, hypotension and elevated JVP is 
suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax develops when there is a parietal or visceral pleural tear. This tear acts as 
a one-way valve i.e. air enters the pleural space from the lung or chest wall during inspiration but 
has no way to escape during expiration, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, acute dyspnea, sudden onset hemodynamic 
compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness), neck vein 
distention, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, decreased chest movements on the 
affected side, hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side and absent or decreased breath 
sounds on the affected side. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed awaiting 
radiological confirmation. Management includes: • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy with a wide bore needle 
in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle 
thoracostomy location is at the 2nd intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line. • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th intercostal space 
in the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is bounded anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major, 
posteriorly by latissmus dorsi and inferiorly by a horizontal line at the level of the nipple. The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area 
devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation 
and the mediastinal shift to the right side. 163 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Options A: Pericardial tamponade can mimic tension pneumothorax, but the absence of a 
tympanic note on percussion rules out its possibility. A patient with pericardial tamponade can 
present with hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds (Beck’s triad), with normal 
breath sounds and no tracheal shift. Option C: Dullness in percussion at the base of the left inferior angle of scapula in conjunction 
with tubular breath sounds (Ewart’s sign), chest pain that improves while sitting upright and 
worsens when lying down and pulsus paradoxus are indicative of pericardial effusion. Pericardial 
effusion develops into tamponade when the effusion leads to increased pressure, impairing 
ventricular filling and reducing cardiac output. Option D: Massive hemothorax is the accumulation of >1500 ml of blood or one-third or more 
of the patient’s blood volume in the chest cavity. The patient will have collapsed neck veins, 
decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 13: A 20-year-old patient presented to the ER with tension pneumothorax following a road traffic 
accident. What is the first line of management?

options.a: Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line
options.b: Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS in the mid-clavicular line
options.c: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-axillary line
options.d: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-clavicular line

questions.explanation:
Insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is the 
first-line management in adults with tension pneumothorax. Management of tension pneumothorax: • Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a 
wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line • Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle 
of safety If a sucking wound is present, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and 
tape on 3 sides. Following this, chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Note: According to ATLS 10th edition 164 
Sold by @itachibot • In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior 
to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line. • In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS 
midclavicular line. This update was recommended since chest wall thickness influences the likelihood of success with 
needle decompression. Inserting needle in 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line had better 
outcomes.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 14: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is 
incorrect?

options.a: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
options.b: Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
options.c: Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.explanation:
An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib at the 5th intercostal 
space (ICS) to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. Hence, option B is incorrect. Chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, and 
pleural effusion in order to drain air/fluid from the pleural space. The triangle of safety, usually in the 5th intercostal space, is the safest site for chest tube insertion, 
it is bound by: • anterior to the midaxillary line • above the horizontal line marked by the level of the nipple • below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle 165 
Sold by @itachibot Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and 
diaphragmatic hernia. Complications of this procedure: • Infection at the site of insertion • Unintentional injury to the lung - hemothorax • Intercostal nerve/ vessel injury • Subcutaneous hematoma/ emphysema
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 15: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by  
.

options.a: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
options.b: Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.explanation:
Oscillation of the water column level (moving up and down during respiration) within the tube in 
the water seal chamber is indicative of a functioning (patent) ICD tube. During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. 
Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known 
as tidaling. Other options: Option A: Continous bubbling indicates an air leak in the drainage system, which should be 
corrected Option B: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its 
functioning. Option C: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year old man is brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to his chest. On 
examination, the patient is found to be hemodynamically unstable. His neck veins are 
engorged and heart sounds are muffled. Which of the following statements about the patient 
is false?

options.a: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
options.b: The entry wound is sealed on all 4 sides with an occlusive dressing if pneumothorax is
options.c: eFAST is done to confirm blood in pericardial sac

questions.explanation:
166 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and muffled heart sounds are suggestive of 
cardiac tamponade. The entry wound is sealed on only 3 sides with an occlusive dressing if a 
pneumothorax is suspected. When there is a pneumothorax with a sucking wound, the immediate step is to cover the wound 
with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides. As the patient breathes in, the dressing occludes the wound, preventing air from entering into the 
thoracic cavity. During exhalation, the open end of the dressing allows air to escape from the 
pleural space. This is known as a flutter-valve effect. Following this, a chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Cardiac tamponade must be di■erentiated from tension pneumothorax in a patient with 
hemodynamic instability and distended neck veins. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck’s triad: • Muffled heart sounds • Distended neck veins • Hypotension Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper resonance on 
percussion on the affected side. These are not present in a patient with cardiac tamponade. Diagnosis of cardiac tamponade can be done by eFAST which shows fluid in the pericardial sac. • Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: Question 17: In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.explanation:
In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable to blast wave (primary blast) injury. 167 
Sold by @itachibot Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an 
explosion. Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by 
an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projecting 
outwards from the point of detonation. They predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow 
organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the middle ear, lungs, 
and GIT. The most sensitive and most frequently injured hollow organs are the tympanic membranes > 
lungs. Blast damage to the lungs is the most common cause of life-threatening injury following an 
explosion. Solid organs are the most resistant to blast injuries as the parenchymal disruption requires very 
high levels of overpressure. Classification of blast injuries: Classification

questions.question:
Question 18: 149 
Sold by @itachibot Following a motor vehicle collision, a 30-year-old male sustained blunt trauma to his 
abdomen. What is the organ most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
The spleen is the most common organ involved in blunt trauma injury of the abdomen. In blunt trauma, organs that cannot yield to impact by elastic deformation are most likely to be 
injured, namely, the solid organs (liver, spleen, and kidneys). For penetrating trauma, organs with the largest surface area when viewed from the front are most 
prone to injury (small bowel, liver, and colon). Additionally, since bullets and knives usually 
follow straight lines, adjacent structures are commonly injured (e.g., the pancreas and 
duodenum). Deceleration injures the pedicled organs by shearing the organs from their points of attachment to 
the retroperitoneum (intestines and kidney). The most commonly injured bowel in cases of blunt trauma of the abdomen is jejunum. 168 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 19: A 30-year-old man stabbed his elder brother using a knife over a property dispute. Which is 
the most common organ that is likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The liver is the most common organ to be injured in penetrating stab injury of the abdomen. It is 
due to its anterior location, size and fragile parenchyma. The most common organ injured in blunt trauma to the abdomen is spleen > liver. The most common organ injured in gunshot injury is the small intestine > colon.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 20: A landlord who was stabbed in his abdomen by one of his tenants for demanding rent was 
brought to the casualty. He was taken up for laparotomy which revealed a severely injured 
cecum. What is the best management option for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The best management option for this patient is right hemicolectomy with ileocolostomy. Injuries proximal to the middle colic artery are best managed by this procedure. Injuries distal to the middle colic artery require segmental resection with colocolostomy 
anastomosis. Immediate anastomosis should be avoided in patients with shock due to the high 
incidence of leaks following the procedure. In such patients, colostomy and delayed primary 
anastomosis should be done. Option A: Catheter tube cecostomy is of therapeutic value in refractory colonic 
pseudo-obstruction, cecal volvulus, or distal colonic obstruction. Option C: Transverse colostomy is generally done in patients with distal obstruction for temporary 
fecal diversion. Option D: An end-loop sigmoid colostomy is an ideal stoma for distal fecal diversion for 
incontinence or in association with complex anorectal procedures.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 21: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of an intra-abdominal 
haemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active bleed from 
the liver. Which of the following techniques will you use to control the bleed?
questions.explanation:
169 
Sold by @itachibot The hepatoduodenal ligament can be clamped to decrease active hemorrhage from the liver. This 
is called Pringle's maneuver. This maneuver applies pressure on the portal triad which contains bile duct, portal vein and 
hepatic artery. This helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic 
vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. The 
liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture 
ligation. 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: • Push - compression of the edges of the laceration • Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad • Plug the defects with silicon tubes • Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient develops abdominal compartment syndrome following an emergency laparotomy. 
Which of the following is false about this condition?
questions.explanation:
Central venous pressure (CVP) increases due to inferior vena cava (IVC) and portal vein 
compression in abdominal compartment syndrome. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS) is defined as increased intra-abdominal pressure 
(IAP) >20 mm Hg resulting in compression of abdominal structures (Normal IAP = 5-7 mmHg 
and intraabdominal hypertension IAP  12 mmHg). This produces fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise. 
Elevated intra-abdominal pressure leads to a decrease in venous return resulting in decreased 
cardiac output. An increase in heart rate partly compensates this. Systemic vascular resistance (afterload) is increased by the compression of both the aorta and 
systemic vasculature. This also leads to an increase in renal vascular resistance leading to a 
reduced glomerular filtration rate. 170 
Sold by @itachibot Causes of primary ACS include: • Abdominal trauma • Hemorrhage • Intestinal obstruction • Retroperitoneal hematoma Causes of secondary ACS include: • Pregnancy • Ascites • Ileus • Intra-abdominal sepsis • Large-volume fluid replacement (greater than 3L)

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following statements about abdominal compartment syndrome is false?

options.b: Hypoxia due to increased peak inspiratory pressure
options.c: Hypotension due to decrease in venous return

questions.explanation:
Oliguria is due to reduced renal blood flow. An increase in renal vascular resistance leads to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and 
impaired urine output. Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by : • A sudden increase in intraabdominal pressure • Increased peak inspiratory pressure • Hypercarbia and respiratory acidosis • Decreased urinary output – due to reduced renal blood flow • Hypotension - secondary to decreased venous return to the heart.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 24: You are evaluating a patient in the burns unit, who had sustained third-degree burns to her 
abdomen and lower limbs (BSA of 30%). She had received 9 liters of Ringer's lactate at a 
primary center. On examination, extensive abdominal eschars are seen. BP - 84/50 mmHg, 
HR - 118 bpm and urine output has been less than 15 ml for the past 2 hours. The ventilator 
shows a peak airway pressure of 42 cm H2O. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). 
Measurement of bladder pressure using a urinary bladder catheter is the next best step in the 
management of this patient. The oliguria and hypotension in isolation could be suggestive of under-resuscitation. However, the 
history of large volume fluid administration, presence of abdominal eschars along with very high 
peak airway pressures should raise the suspicion for ACS. Abdominal compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of intra-abdominal pressure > 
20mmHg with associated organ compression and dysfunction: • Compression of the IVC leads to decreased cardiac output, and consequent increase in systemic 
vascular resistance, leading to hypotension. 171 
Sold by @itachibot • Cephalad displacement of the diaphragm results in decreased thoracic volumes and results in 
elevated peak and plateau pressures. • Renal compression can lead to increased renal vascular resistance, decreased GFR and low urine 
output. Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for 
intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome. Note: Direct methods such as pressure transducers and intraperitoneal catheters are more 
accurate but are limited by their invasiveness. Grade of Intra-abdominal hy

questions.question:
Question 25: 151 
Sold by @itachibot A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit following a trauma to the abdomen. His 
intraabdominal pressure is found to be 24 mmHg. What is the grade of abdominal 
hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Intraabdominal pressure (IAP) of 24 mm Hg falls under grade III of intra-abdominal hypertension 
(IAH). Normal intraabdominal pressure is 5 to 7 mmHg. Any acute process in the abdomen such as 
trauma, intestinal perforation, peritonitis, or acute pancreatitis can increase the intra-abdominal 
pressure. Increased abdominal pressure can diminish the blood flow to the abdominal organs and 
decrease the venous return to the heart. Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for 
intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome. Grade III intra-abdominal hypertension is associated with hypoxia, ARDS and serious 
complications. It is associated with abdominal compartment syndrome which is defined as a 
sustained IAP >20 mmHg associated with organ dysfunction/failure. Grade of Intra-abdominal hy

questions.question:
Question 26: Following a road traffic accident, a child presents with abdominal pain. On examination, 
vitals are stable and tenderness is present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best 
investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
172 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following 
a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in a 
hemodynamically stable patient. Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Radiological investigations 
are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock in combination with microscopic haematuria, 
pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries. CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, 
extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and 
effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the 
normal renal contour. Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most of the penetrating injuries require surgical 
renal exploration. Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are: • Massive hemorrhage • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury) • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma Relative indications are: • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction • Bowel or pancreatic injuries • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys • Renal hypertension Exploratory laparotomy is recommended in stable patients with penetrating renal injuries.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 27: A trauma patient suffers a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He is managed 
conservatively. However, after a few days, he presents with a urinoma. The next best 
management for this patient would be?
questions.explanation:
The patient with a history of grade IV renal injury (renal laceration with urine extravasation) who 
develops a persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be 
managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent. In patients not cured by ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drain 
may be required. Management of renal injuries Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Blunt trauma is mostly 
treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration. • Grading of injury through CECT • If hemodynamically stable • Conservative management - Bedrest & hemodynamic monitoring 173 
Sold by @itachibot • In grade IV, a repeat CT scan to ensure the extravasation of urine has resolved. • If hemodynamically unstable • Surgical exploration and repair • In grade V, nephrectomy.

questions.question:
Question 28: While performing emergency laparotomy for an unstable RTA case with blunt abdominal 
trauma, the surgeon notices a hematoma around the left kidney. What will be the next step in 
the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
The next step in the surgical management of the patient found to have a hematoma around the 
kidney, intraoperatively, will be a single-shot intravenous pyelography (IVP). If immediate operative exploration for other injuries is required, renal injury staging can be 
performed while the patient is still in the operating room, using single-shot IVP. It is useful in 
assessing the function of the kidneys and the extent of the injury. If the IVP is abnormal or the 
hematoma is pulsatile, then renal exploration should be performed. Note: CECT is the method of choice for staging a patient with hemodynamically stable renal 
trauma presenting at the emergency room.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal  Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question:
Question 29: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the 
abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most 
appropriate management for this child?
questions.explanation:
Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child. Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in: • Stable patients with no active bleeding • Patients younger than 55 years of age • Patients with grade I, II, III injuries. Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V 
splenic injury should be managed by surgery. 174

questions.question:
Question 31: A young male patient is taken up for laparotomy following a stab injury. Pringle’s maneuver 
is done. Which of the following statements is false about this maneuver?

options.a: It is used to differentiate between hepatic arterial and hepatic venous bleed
options.b: Arterial bleed persists on performing the maneuver
options.c: Hepatic pedicle is compressed at the epiploic foramen
options.d: Prolonged application of pressure can lead to hepatic necrosis

questions.explanation:
Pringle maneuver may be required for the treatment of liver laceration. Hepatic venous 
bleed persists on performing this maneuver. When there is severe bleeding from the liver, this maneuver is a viable adjunct to slow blood flow 
enough to visualize liver injury. The hepatoduodenal ligament is clamped at the epiploic foramen 
or the foramen of Winslow. This applies pressure on the portal triad that contains bile duct, portal 
vein and hepatic artery. This helps to distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from 
hepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist when the hepatoduodenal ligament 
clamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled 
with suture ligation. 176 
Sold by @itachibot 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: • Push - compression of the edges of the laceration • Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad • Plug the defects with silicon tubes • Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding. Prolonged intraoperative use of Pringle maneuver can lead to hepatic ischemia and necrosis.

questions.question:
Question 32: An elderly lady presents to the trauma care centre following a motor vehicle collision. She 
complains of chest pain and abdominal pain. On examination, breath sounds are decreased 153 
Sold by @itachibot on the right side. X ray chest revealed the following finding. Which of the following 
statements is false regarding the management of this patient?

options.a: Most accurate evaluation of this condition is by VATS
options.b: Operative repair is indicated in all cases
options.c: In case of penetrating injury, repair can be done via thoracic incision
options.d: The defect must be closed with polypropylene sutures

questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and X-ray image showing obliteration of the diaphragmatic outline are 
suggestive of traumatic diaphragmatic injury in this patient. Penetrating diaphragmatic injury 
must be repaired via the abdomen and not the thorax, to rule out penetrating hollow viscus 
injury. Patients with diaphragmatic injury are generally asymptomatic. Chest X ray after the insertion of 
a nasogastric tube may help in identifying the herniation of the stomach in the thoracic cavity. 
However, the most accurate evaluation is by video assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) or laparoscopy. 
Abdominal contents may get herniated into the chest and get strangulated later. This is associated 
with high mortality. Hence, operative repair is indicated in all patients. The defect is closed with 
running 1-0 polypropylene suture.

questions.question:
Question 33: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being involved in a high-speed motorcycle 
collision. He is hypotensive with a systolic pressure of 60 mm Hg. A FAST scan is positive. At 
laparotomy, he is found to have a large amount of bleeding from behind the liver with 
hollow-viscous perforation. Temporary application of a Pringle manoeuvre does not control 
the bleeding. However, laparotomy packs are placed, and the bleeding appears to slow down. 
The systolic blood pressure fails to increase even after aggressive resuscitation. The patient’s 
pH is 7.06 and his temperature is 34°C. What would be the next best step in the management 
of this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient has a blunt trauma abdomen. He is hypothermic and he is battling acidosis. Thus, he 
should be subjected to damage control surgery and must be shifted to ICU for further 
resuscitation. 177 
Sold by @itachibot Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite 
surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive 
resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. 3 Phases : Phase I (Initial Exploration) - This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active 
hemorrhage and contamination. Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) - This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, 
coagulopathy, and acidosis. Phase III (Definitive Operation) - It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically 
occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation. Pringle's manoeuvre can be performed to decrease the active haemorrhage from the liver in a liver 
laceration. It is done by applying pressure on the portal triad at the Foramen of Winslow. The 
pressure can be applied either digitally or with the use of a soft clamp. Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in 
the free edge of the lesser omentum. Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right 
lobe of the liver. Structures entering at porta hepatis: • Portal vein • Hepatic artery • Hepatic nervous plexus Structures exiting the porta hepatis: • Right and left hepatic bile ducts • Lymphatics The images attached below shows the porta hepatis and the gif demonstrates the pringles 
manoeuvre. 178 
Sold by @itachibot 179 
Sold by @itachibot 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad • Plug the defects with silicon tubes • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding General guidelines for the management of blunt trauma to the liver: • Patients who are haemodynamically unstable will require an immediate laparotomy for damage 
control resuscitation. • For the patient who is haemodynamically stable, imaging by CT should be performed to further 
evaluate the nature of the injury. • Most patients with a blunt liver injury who are haemodynamically stable can be managed 
conservatively. • The indication for discontinuing conservative treatment is the development of haemodynamic 
instability, evidence of ongoing blood loss despite correction of any underlying coagulopathy and 
the development of signs of generalised peritonitis. • Interventional radiology has an important role in the management of liver trauma and 
embolisation to control hepatic artery bleeding is safe and effective in a stable patient with no 
evidence of hollow viscus perforation. 180
